Title: Beethoven EROICA 15 March 1988 Tennstedt
Description:
Beethoven Symphony no 3 "Eroica"
New York Philharmonic Orchestra
Klaus Tennstedt
New York 15 March 1988.

The performance of this symphony 10 days earlier in was hailed  by one NY critic as the greatest Eroica ever! This performance is the same or very similar. I will leave you to decide that for yourselves. This is the broadest, Grandest most dynamic slow movement I have ever heard. It is monumental. Occasional radio interference.

Title: Brahms Double Concerto op. 102 Tennstedt
Description:
Brahms Double Concerto opus 102
Ulf Hölscher, violin
Heinrich Schiff, cello
NDR Symphony Orchestra
Philharmonie Berlin 24 February 1981.

This was the beginning of the fateful NDR SO tour in 1981 that saw
Tennstedt resign after the Paris concert on the 6th March and Kondrashin, who replaced him the next evening in Amsterdam, die of a heart attack in his hotel room after the very successful concert.

Title: Brahms Symphony No. 3 (Tennstedt/London Symphony Orch.)
Description: To anyone that still regularly watches any of my videos that is reading this. The reason I made my channel was because I wanted full recordings of classical pieces for a giant playlist that I could listen to without interruption. At the time I thought that hosting the playlist on Youtube was my best option. In 2021 I realized that this was not the case and that it would be better to host the playlist on Spotify which is why I stopped uploading. If you're interested in listening to what I consider to be the definitive interpretations of my personal favorite symphonic works the completed Spotify playlist link is as follows https://open.spotify.com/playlist/70UaByYqmFmO8vOjiiSPaY?si=e2031dd54b56490f. Enjoy!

Title: EXCELLENT: Sibelius: Violin Concerto, Yuval Yaron, Tennstedt / Bavarian Radio S.O. live, 1978
Description:
Sibelius:
Violin Concerto
Yuval Yaron, violin

Klaus Tennstedt /
Bavarian Radio S.O.
live, 1978 

This is without the slightest doubt one of the absolute best recordings of the concerto.

Yaron won the Sibelius Violin Competition in 1975. This 1978 live concert was only released in 2005, and is a real "sleeper".

Here we all three (the soloist, the conductor, and myself) agree on how a proper and effective Sibelius should be accomplished. 
Yaron is both very precise and very interpretative, but the slow part could have been more plain in my opinion.

Yaron's performance is one of the very few there are where the pitch is perfect throughout. Call me a pitch autist if you like, but I demand that. 

The orchestra (mostly the timpani) is at places a bit out of synch for the difficult rhythmic pattern in the very fast-paced (which is the right way) final. 
I just read an article where it was found out that in recent times, the very fast tempo defined by Sibelius of the final part has slowed down appreciably in the real performances. What would be the reason? Less skill? Less ambition?


Paintings / sketches for paintings by Akseli Gallen-Kallela.

Title: F. Liszt. Concerto #2 for Piano and Orchestra (Lazar Berman, K.Tennstedt, London Symphony Orchestra)
Description:
What a fantastic recording!  I wish the quality was better, because both Berman and Tennstedt are great.  Is there any other recording of this Concerto with such unbelievable unity of interpretation?  The soloist and the orchestra sound like one body. 
Great thanks to Mark Hood at https://youtu.be/aJwtR9zNmXA for publishing this jewel.

*   *   *

Какая фантастическая запись!  К сожалению, качество записи не из лучших, но и Берман, и Теннштедт великолепны.  Существует ли другое исполнение этого Концерта с таким единством интерпретации?  Солист и оркестр звучат как одно тело. 

Большое спасибо Марку Худу (https://youtu.be/aJwtR9zNmXA) за публикацию этой драгоценности.

Title: Klaus Tennstedt and the Mecklenburgische Staatskapelle Schwerin - Beethoven Symphony no.1 in C major
Description:
Klaus Tennstedt and the Mecklenburgische Staatskapelle Schwerin with Beethoven's symphony no.1 in C major.  August 18-19, 1968 (studio recording).  
"Although the Mecklenburgische Staatskapelle Schwerin is nobody's idea of a world-class orchestra, under Tennstedt in the First its playing is full of light and clarity and elegance and wit."  James Leonard, AllMusic
"Particularly impressive is No. 1. In many respects, it recalls the old Weingartner recording: never rushed, yet aptly buoyant and animated in outer movements, and pointedly flowing in its con moto andante . Interestingly, too, this provincial orchestra is more polished technically than Weingartner’s 1937 Vienna Philharmonic."  Mortimer H. Frank, Fanfare magazine

1)  Adagio molto - Allegro con brio
2)  Andante cantabile con moto
3)  Menuetto: Allegro e vivace
4)  Adagio - Allegro molto e vivace

And hear Klaus Tennstedt rehearse the first and second movements here:
1st movement:   https://youtu.be/Uj3pQkg7Jn4 
2nd movement:  https://youtu.be/KfnPnEoMkTc

Title: Leonore Overture No. 3: MET: Tennstedt (LIVE!)
Description:
Leonore Overture No. 3, Op. 72b, by Ludwig van Beethoven (December 17, 1770 - March 26, 1827) MET Orchestra, Klaus Tennstedt (June 6, 1926 - January 11, 1998) conductor: live broadcast.

By James Kreger, Cellist, MET Orchestra:
Here is an excerpt from the January 7, 1984 live Metropolitan Opera broadcast of Beethoven's only opera Fidelio. It was conductor Klaus Tennstedt's American opera conducting début. Erich Leinsdorf, Music Director of the Boston Symphony and Arturo Toscanini's assistant, was a regular conductor at the MET for several decades. The Fidelio production in 1984 incorporated Leinsdorf's plan to play the Leonore Overture No. 3 as a segue from the Dungeon Scene to the Finale of the opera. You will hear the final notes of the duet between Leonore (Fidelio) and Florestan with applause dissolving into the opening of the Overture. The unbelievable, heart-stopping audience reception following the MET Orchestra's inspiring performance of Leonore No. 3 nearly raised the roof off the house, leading segue into the Finale. The cast was about as good as you could get: Jon Vickers was legendary as Florestan. With his total commitment he literally 'became' the role and in the process raised the level of everyone else. Eva Marton was Leonore, Roberta Peters played Marzelline, Matti Salminen was Rocco, Franz Mazura, Pizzaro, and Aage Haugland as Don Fernando. The production was by Otto Schenk. And then there was Klaus Tennstedt. From the outset of the very first rehearsal one could sense his total, life and death, commitment to the score. That made the orchestra even more eager to reciprocate in kind. Those incredible moments on January 7, 1984 made me feel privileged to be part of this great orchestra and will remain with me forever as one of the high points of my career. Following is a portion of the December 15, 1983 review of the premiere by Donal Henahan, Chief Music Critic, The New York Times:
"Even before Klaus Tennstedt lifted his baton to make his American opera debut as the leader of the season's first ''Fidelio,'' he was given a long, fervent ovation. The cheering was repeated at every subsequent opportunity, perhaps as an expression of the audience's gratitude at finding one of the world's foremost conductors in the Metropolitan's pit, even if as a passing guest. Mr. Tennstedt responded by leading a high-tension performance of ''Fidelio'' that often stretched the dramatic line near the breaking point, particularly in a passionate reading of the ''Leonore'' Overture No. 3, gratuitously played as usual before the final scene. This was not a 'Fidelio' especially rich in orchestral or vocal nuance. What Mr. Tennstedt seemed to be aiming for, on the whole, was heart-stopping melodrama and a musical line that never fell slack for a moment. That is certainly one valid way to approach this most melodramatic of operas. One could imagine Beethoven himself conducting it along the same lines."

Title: Mahler Symphony no 9 Tennstedt New York 1982
Description:
Mahler Symphony no 9
New York Philharmonic Orchestra
Avery Fisher Hall (Lincoln Center) New York
18 February 1982
Tennstedt conducted the 9th in Philadelphia in January 1982 and this performance in New York some 7 weeks later. This performance has
the visceral quality that Tennstedt brought so often to his Mahler perfromances and this is the one to hear. His 9th symphony interpretation almost tears one apart listening to it. One of the greatest performances of this symphony by the greatest conductor I ever saw in all my 55 years of concert going. In saying that, I rank only Furtwängler higher than this.

Title: Mahler Symphony No. 6 - London Philharmonic Orchestra - Klaus Tennstedt (Royal Albert Hall, 1983)
Description:
This BBC Promenade Concert was given on 22 August 1983 in the Royal Albert Hall, London. I was in two minds as to whether to upload this recording this I can see that it is already available on YouTube although I could only see it published as the individual movements and not as a whole. So my apologies if you have already listened to this but for the sake of completeness I thought I would upload this recording since it is one of the few I (unfortunately) have of the late, great Klaus Tennstedt.

London Philharmonic Orchestra
conducted by
Klaus Tennstedt

For more details see: https://www.bbc.co.uk/events/ez4rzc

This is part of a collection of live "off air" recordings from radio broadcasts I have made since 1970, and I have recently preserved by transferring from tape to digital format. None of the recordings is derived from a commercial release, nor are they of commercial sound quality. No payment is sought for listening to these recordings, I am sharing them in the hope that they may give pleasure to other music lovers, as they have given pleasure to me. No copyright infringement is intended, please do contact me to allow me to correct the situation should this be the case.

Title: Mozart piano concerto no 12.  Karl Engel with Klaus Tennstedt and the Deutsches Symphonie-Orchester.
Description:
Karl Engel (piano) with Klaus Tennstedt and the Deutsches Symphonie-Orchester Berlin, September 1973.  
Karl Engel, a Swiss pianist, recorded the complete piano music of Mozart and of Robert Schumann and made numerous recordings with Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, Hermann Prey and  Brigitte Fassbaender.   
In 1973 Klaus Tennstedt held the post of Music Director at Kiel.  He  was invited  as guest-conductor by several West German orchestras in the run-up to the 1974 'breakthrough' that took him to Canada, the USA and eventually, in 1976, to  the UK.

Two sprightly movements and a beautifully-paced 'andante', thought to have been Mozart's tribute to the recently-deceased Johann Christian Bach.
1)  Allegro
2)  Andante
3)  Rondeau (Allegretto)

Note:  It's NOT the worst piano in Berlin!  Original CD has excellent sound, but listened to via the internet there's a little tolerable distortion in the higher registers. 
(This is a Berlin studio recording.)

Title: Richard Wagner - Götterdämmerung - Siegfried's death and Funeral march - Klaus Tennstedt
Description:
Götterdämmerung - Twilight of the Gods, WWV 86D, is the last in Richard Wagner's cycle of four music dramas titled Der Ring des Nibelungen (The Ring of the Nibelung, or The Ring Cycle or The Ring for short). It received its premiere at the Bayreuth Festspielhaus on 17th of August 1876, as part of the first complete performance of the whole work.

In the video are parts of "Siegfried" which is part of "Die Nibelungen" ("The Nibelungs") a two-part series of silent fantasy films created by Austrian director Fritz Lang in 1924 - for the German UFA - consisting of Die Nibelungen: Siegfried and Die Nibelungen: Kriemhild's Revenge.
The scenarios for both films were co-written by Lang's then-wife Thea von Harbou, based upon the epic poem Nibelungenlied written around AD 1200. Die Nibelungen received its UK premiere at the Royal Albert Hall in London, where it played for 40 performances between 29th of April and 20th of June 1924. Siegfried was released in the United States on 23rd of August 1925, premiering at the Century Theatre in New York City in the short-lived Phonofilm sound-on-film process. Kriemhild's Revenge was released in the U.S. in 1928.

Paul Richter as Siegfried the dragon slayer, Margarete Schön as Kriemhild and Hans Adalbert Schlettow as Hagen von Tronje. 

Cinematography: Carl Hoffmann, Gunther Rittau and Walter Ruttmann.
Directed by Fritz Lang - 1924. 
Author: Richard Wagner - 1876. 
Conductor: Klaus Tennstedt and the London Philharmonic Orchestra. Live in Tokyo - 1988. 

Video created by Torsten Lang OMCLA/LAVA 2023.

#classicalmusic #classicmusic #richardwagner

Tennstedt was once described as the "Greatest Guest Conductor in the World". From 1974 onwards "Tenn" would regularly conduct the "Big Five"
orchestras in the USA - New York, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Chicago and Boston. He also conducted the San Francisco SO, Pittsburg SO, Cincinnati, Detroit, Dallas and the National Symphony in Washington. He also became Chief Guest conductor with the Minnesota Orchestra. 
Every one of his concerts was a Gem. This one is no exception.
Henryk Szeryng at his best.

Title: The Bartered Bride Overture - Klaus Tennstedt conducts the London Philharmonic Orchestra, 1991
Description:
Tennstedt chose this overture from Bedřich Smetana's comic opera 'The Bartered Bride' to open a programme of Czech music featuring  Antonin Dvořák's symphony no. 8 and ending with Leoš Janáček's 'Sinfonietta'.
Music critic Edward Greenfield wrote in the Guardian:-  "... a fizzing performance of Smetana's Bartered Bride Overture.  The speed was so hectic, you thought it might all come off the rails, but instead a meticulous precision was achieved even in the most rapid string passages."

Back in 1955 Smetana's popular comic opera 'The Bartered Bride' (Die Verkaufte Braut) was one of the first productions Tennstedt conducted as Assistant Music Director in Chemnitz (then known as Karl-Marx-Stadt).

First broadcast live on BBC Radio 3, 1991. 
(Photo by Clive Barda. )

Title: シューベルト／交響曲第9番ハ長調 D944「ザ・グレート」／テンシュテット／ベルリン・フィル（1983 4 19）
Description:
ブログ「寸草春暉」2014年6月29日
http://blog.goo.ne.jp/tgcy2801　（C4524B）
（1983年4月19日 ベルリン・フィルハーモニーホールにて収録 自由ベルリン放送協会提供の録音テープによる） 1984年3月21日エアチェック

　平成生まれの人は、ドイツのベルリンが東西に分断されていた事実は、歴史でしか知らないわけですね。西ベルリンにあったベルリン・フィルハーモニーホールでの収録番組は、「自由ベルリン放送協会提供のテープ」と案内されてました。東ドイツにあった、例えば、ドレスデン国立歌劇場管の演奏ですと、ドイツ民主ラジオ提供のテープと案内されていました。

この曲は大曲です。長いということです。いっその事、BGMで流してください。

テノール）ロバート・ティアー　バリトン）グウィン・ハウエル
1985年9月13日　ロンドン・プロムス音楽祭　ライブ録音
※1985年プロムス音楽祭の掉尾を飾ったテンシュテットの公演。モーツァルトとベートーヴェンの最後の交響曲を並べて演奏した同公演はプロムス史上でも歴史的名公演と言われました。テンシュテットはこの直後のアメリカ公演で咽頭がんを発症、その後の演奏活動を休止、制限することになったので、ある意味この時が彼の音楽の集大成であったと言えるかもしれません。
